column7: The cabinet is replete with partisans who only see one side of the problem.

column3: something present in inadequate quantities
column7: There was a relative paucity of evidences in the sensational case.

column3: relatively minor fault or sin
column7: Part time gambling was one of his many peccadillos.

column3: relating to or involving money
column7: The dot com bubble burst lead to major pecuniary losses to many.

column3: the art or science of teaching or education
column7: The college boasts the most progressive pedagogy and a 100% placement rate.

column3: excessively concerned with minor details or rules
column7: He was disgusted at the pedantic teaching style in his new college.

column3: triangular part above columns in Greek buildings
column7: The pediment was the crowning feature of the Greek temple front.

column3: transparent, easy to understand
column7: One could see the bottom of the flowing river because of the pellucid water.

column3: strong, habitual liking for something
column7: Her penchant for physics helped her to become a mechanical engineer.

column3: feeling or showing regret for something morally wrong, remorseful
column7: Post the bloodbath at Kalinga, Ashoka became a penitent sinner.

column3: extreme poverty, indigence
column7: People in the remote villages are living in absolute penury.

column3: a journey, esp. a long, meandering one
column7: She tagged along with her aunt on all her peregrinations.

column3: insisting immediate attention (often rudely)
column7: It was a peremptory order from the court.

column3: deceitful and untrustworthy
column7: The local drug dealers were betrayed by a perfidious ally.

column3: done as a duty without care
column7: He made a perfunctory statement supporting the chairman.

column3: going from place to place, usually as part of a job
column7: He worked as a peripatetic journalist for most of his life.

column3: wilfully giving false statement under oath
column7: He was found guilty of perjury and charged on three more infractions.

column3: harmful, injurious
column7: Televisions have a pernicious influence on our children.

column3: light teasing, banter
column7: The friends who were engaged in persiflage could not stop laughing.

column3: pleasing in appearance and manner, likeable
column7: He was so personable and well-spoken, that everybody gravitated towards him.

column3: acutely insightful and wise, quick judging
column7: She considers herself a perspicacious judge of character.

column3: transparently clear, easily understandable
column7: The lecture made the essay more perspicuous to the students.

column3: relevant or pertinent to a subject under consideration
column7: The students asked the teacher many pertinent questions about politics.

column3: to examine with great care
column7: As part of an assignment, he perused the Taj Mahal with sincerity.

column3: permeate or spread throughout
column7: The ill effects of the Great Depression pervaded Europe.

column3: turn to stone infer and terror
column7: The thought of speaking with the principal petrified her.

column3: childishly sulky or bad tempered
column7: When the child was not given his gift, he became petulant and angry.

column3: charity, desire to do good for mankind
column7: The family's philanthropy made it possible to build the school for poor.

column3: a smug, ignorant person who lacks knowledge
column7: A philistine public concerned only with celebrities from one sport.

column3: having an unemotional and calm disposition, imperturbable
column7: She was phlegmatic even during the most difficult moments of the crisis.

column3: relating to a rogue and dishonest, but appealing hero
column7: Unlike his other works, the new book is a picaresque adventure novel.

column3: of mixed colors
column7: Although the father’s coat was pure solid brown, the mother’s was pied.

column3: to punish, hold up to public scorn
column7: The politician found himself pilloried by members of his own party.

column3: suffer a mental and physical decline because of losing someone
column7: Post their divorce, the man was still pining for his wife.

column3: devoted to religion
column7: Our neighbours are pious churchgoing people.

column3: having a pleasantly sharp and agreeable taste
column7: They were served starters with various piquant sauces.

column3: hurt the pride and made angry and irritated
column7: After a moment of pique, the mayor responded calmly to his accusers.

column3: essential and most important part of something
column7: The rebuttal was digressing from the pith of the debate’s topic.

column3: of great importance to something
column7: The coach played a pivotal role in the development of the player’s technique.

column3: sounding sad and mournful, melancholy
column7: We could hear the plaintive cries of the relatives when the patient died.

column3: flat metal awarded as a memorial; sticky deposit on teeth
column7: They gave him a plaque commemorating his lifetime service for the company.

column3: a flat, dull statement, banal, trite
column7: His speech was filled with familiar platitudes about the value of hard work.

column3: the common people, commoner
column7: He doesn't think the novel will appeal to their plebeian tastes.

column3: more than required, extreme excess
column7: A plethora of researches have been done on the subject.

column3: able to bend and move freely without breaking
column7: The dancer’s body was extremely pliant considering his body weight.

column3: continue doing a dull task without resting
column7: I suppose I will just have to plod through the whole book.

column3: measure the depth of
column7: I plumbed the depth and found the bottom of the tank to be ten metres down.

column3: deeply moving and evoking sadness, mournful
column7: The father of the murder victim bade a poignant farewell to his son.

column3: involving strongly critical, writing or speech, controversial
column7: The polemical essay in the newspaper incensed a few people.

column3: slow and clumsy because of great weight
column7: The students struggled to stay awake during a ponderous lecture.

column3: a sign that a calamitous event is likely to happen, omen
column7: Many birds are regarded as being portents of death.

column3: talk at length in a foolish or inconsequential way
column7: She began to prattle on about her visit to the dentist.

column3: preliminary introduction to something, preface, prologue
column7: He told us the sad news without any preamble.

column3: dangerously likely to fall or collapse
column7: Driving through the mountains at night is precarious and deadly.

column3: rules establishing standards of conduct
column7: The legal precept of being innocent until proven guilty.

column3: hurl or throw violently or occurring abruptly
column7: It led to a precipitous slide in the government's popularity.

column3: prevent from happening, make impossible
column7: The secret nature of his work precluded official recognition.

column3: premature or advanced development of a child
column7: She was a precocious child who could read before she went to school.

column3: something that happens before others
column7: Small tremors may be precursors to big earthquakes.

column3: special liking, mental preference or predisposition
column7: They shared a predilection for adventurous hikes.

column3: tidy oneself up
column7: She stood preening herself in front of the mirror.

column3: the quality or fact of being greater in number or importance
column7: The preponderance of visitors to the aquarium are from outside the country.

column3: warning sign for something ill-fated event in the future
column7: Investors are worried that the war could presage another recession.

column3: ability to predict what will happen in future
column7: She was remarkably prescient about the outcome of the final match.

column3: assumption of something as true, based on probability
column7: He lifted her off the ground, and she was enraged at his presumption.

column3: beyond what is normal or natural
column7: She has a preternatural ability to charm people.

column3: to speak falsely or misleadingly, conceal the truth
column7: Government officials prevaricated about the real costs of the project.
